questions.text: What would be the appropriate next step in the management of a 55-year-old female patient who has a 4x3 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant, with no involvement of axillary lymph nodes, and a BIRADS 4b staging on mammography? The patient underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final histopathology examination (HPE) report indicated high nuclear-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with necrosis and a 10mm margin clearance.

options.label: C
options.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Adjuvant Radioth

questions.text: Which of the following carries the lowest risk of developing invasive ductal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
No increased risk    Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
    

  • Apocrine metaplasia

  •     Cysts, macro and/or micro

  •     Duct ectasia

  •     Fibroadenoma

  •     Fibrosis

  •     Hyperplasia

  •     Mastitis (inflammation)

  •     Periductal mastitis

  •     Squamous metaplasia 

Slightly increased risk (1.5 – 2 times)     

 

Moderately increased risk (5 times)    

  • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid or papillary    

  • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core 

  • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular)

Insufficient data to assign a risk     

  • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus 

  •     Radial Scar lesion

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who complains of a painless mass in her left breast that can be felt? The mass is highly movable, measures 3 x 3 cm, and has a rubbery texture.

What preoperative intervention can be administered to minimise intraoperative bleeding in a 32-year-old female patient diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting with eye symptoms and an enlarged thyroid, who is scheduled to undergo a total thyroidectomy?
questions.explanation:
Grave’s Disease

Pathogenesis

  • An autoimmune disorder characterised by the production of long-acting thyroid stimulator (LATS) or thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies against the TSH receptor, which results in Hyperthyroidism.
  • Increased beta-receptor expression results in sympathetic stimulation (Tachycardia, Fine tremors, Sweating).

Characteristic Features
  • Thyrotoxicosis (Symptoms of Hyperthyroidism)
  • Ophthalmopathy (Exophthalmos): Accumulation of areolar tissue behind the eye.
  • Pretibial Myxedema
  • Gynaecomastia

Diagnosis
  • Clinical: Presence of eye signs in hyperthyroid patients.
  • Confirmatory Test: Detection of thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies.

Eye Signs
  • Stellwag's Sign: Reduced blink rate or incomplete blinking.
  • Dalrymple’s Sign: Visible upper sclera with lid retraction
  • Von Graefe's Sign: Lid lag on down gaze
  • Joffroy's Sign: Absence of Forehead wrinkling on Upgaze
  • Moebius Sign: Loss of Accommodation

Management

Medical management:

  • Propranolol (provide symptomatic relief)
  • Antithyroid drugs like Propylthiouracil (DOC in 1st trimester), Methimazole, and Carbimazole (Can be given in 2n and 3rd trimesters)

Surgical Intervention: Total Thyroidectomy is the treatment of choice, especially when other methods fail or are contraindicated (Lugol’s iodine is used for the pre-operative preparation).

  • Adults with Goiter are managed by drugs followed by surgery.
  • Radioactive Iodine (RAI) Ablation:
    • Indications: Elderly patients with surgical comorbidities or recurrence after surgery.
    • Contraindications: Pregnancy, Lactation, Patient with eye signs (worsens Ophthalmopathy)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a relative contraindication for breast conservative surgery?
questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications
  • First-trimester Pregnancy
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse Suspicious microcalcifications on mammogram
  • Extensive DCIS
  • Inflammatory Breast Cancer
  • Tumors for which Clear Margins are Unobtainable with Lumpectomy
  • Homozygous for ATM Mutation

Relative Contraindications
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast (Option C ruled out)
  • Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins
  • Large Tumor Size Relative to Breast Size or Tumors >5 cm (Option A)
  • Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation) (Option B ruled out)
  • Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2) (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: What is the appropriate next step in managing a 37-year-old unmarried woman who has never given birth, is sexually active, and is currently taking oral contraceptive pills, considering that her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 60 and her older sister was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 40?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic counseling and screening for BRCA

options.label: C
options.text: Stop taking oral and contraceptive pills

questions.correct_answer: A. Genetic counseling and screening for BRCA
questions.explanation:
Modifiable risk factors

Non-modifiable risk factors

Obesity: BMI > 30 (RR= 1.29)

Age

  • Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK, USA), While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India.

Nulliparous women or first pregnancy after 35 years

Sex

  • Female sex is a risk factor
  • Male sex accounts for 0.5-1% of all breast cancer

Breastfeeding is a protective factor

Ethnicity

American white, African-American Parsi in India

Use of Hormonal Replacement Therapy (HRT) >10 years (RR= 1.2)

Family history of breast cancer

  • 1 first-degree relative RR= 2
  • 2 first-degree relative RR= 3

Tobacco use (RR=1.07-1.14)

Genetic predisposition

BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations account for 70% of hereditary breast cancers

Alcohol Consumption (RR = 1.05-1.32)

Early Menarche(<12years)

Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19

Radiation exposure (RR=6)

Late Menopause(>55years)

Increases by about 3% for each year later menopause begins RR=1.12

Age at first child

 
  • <20years - Less risk
  • >35years - High risk

High-risk breast lesions

  • Complex fibroadenoma RR=3
  • Papillomatosis RR=3
  • Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10

questions.text: A lump in the breast is observed in a female patient. Among the options listed below, all but one can be employed to exclude the presence of cancer. Which one is not applicable for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
1. Clinical Examination (Option C ruled out)

Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy.

Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes.

2. Imaging (Option A ruled out)

Methods:

  • Mammography: Preferred for women over 40.
  • Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation.

3. Biopsy

(Option D ruled out)

Types:

  • FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions.
  • Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses.
  • Excisional: Removes lump for examination.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, the fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the management plan for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision. (Option A)
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews of culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump, which she noticed on a self-breast examination 3 weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. FNAC is characterized by stromal and epithelial elements with no signs of malignancy. What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Reassurance and follow-up

Fibroadenoma

Definition
  • Benign tumors arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast

Prevalence
  • Most common in women aged 15-25 years

Aetiology
  • Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps
  • Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast"

Diagnosis
  • Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy)
  • Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts
  • Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring
  • Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis
  • Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision

Prognosis
  • Benign, do not increase risk of breast cancer
  • Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes
  • Recurrence is uncommon

Relationship to ANDI
  • Categorised according to ANDI as:
    • Normal: Small fibroadenomas (≤1 cm)
    • Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas (≤3 cm)
    • Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localised erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, and the fluctuation test is positive. Mild axillary lymphadenopathy is on the affected side, and the contralateral breast is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Breast abscess

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms
  • Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, and culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented with a swelling in her neck. She had an exposure to radiation in the past. Identify the type of disease, image of FNAC is given below:
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Papillary Carcinoma

Feature

Details

Definition

Most common thyroid malignancy (80–85%) with excellent prognosis.

Risk Factors

Childhood radiation exposure, BRAF & RET/PTC mutations, family history.

Spread

Lymphatic spread (cervical lymph nodes commonly affected).

Clinical Features

Painless thyroid nodule, cervical lymphadenopathy, euthyroid state.

Histopathology

Orphan Annie eye nuclei, Psammoma bodies, Nuclear grooves, Papillary structures with fibrovascular cores.

Diagnosis

1. Ultrasound – Microcalcifications, hypoechoic nodule, irregular margins. 2. FNAC – First-line test.

Treatment

1. Total thyroidectomy (>1 cm, multifocal, lymph node involvement). 2. Lobectomy (<1 cm, no metastasis). 3. RAI therapy (for residual disease or metastasis). 4. TSH suppression therapy (Levothyroxine).

Prognosis

Excellent (>95% 10-year survival). Worse with older age, distant metastasis, large tumor size, BRAF mutation.

Luminal A

ER+, PR+, HER2-

Luminal B

ER+, PR±, HER2±

Responds to endocrine therapy but has higher proliferation than Luminal A

HER2+ (non-luminal)

ER-, PR-, HER2+

Poorer prognosis

Requires Trastuzumab (Herceptin)

Triple-negative (Basal-like)

ER-, PR-, HER2-

Worst prognosis

Chemotherapy is the only option; high recurrence

questions.text: In the surgical procedure for breast carcinoma, a frozen section was performed. This technique has benefits for all individuals, with the exception of:

options.label: D
options.text: To confirm definitive diagnosis immediately in all cases

questions.correct_answer: D. To confirm definitive diagnosis immediately in all cases

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and prior radiation therapy presents with a right-sided thyroid swelling. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) confirms papillary carcinoma with no evidence of lymph node involvement. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemi-thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

options.label: C
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

questions.text: Fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) is required in which of the following interpretations of HER2/NEU?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) 2+

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true? 1. Due to increasing mammography there occurs over diagnosis of breast carcinoma 2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination 3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection 4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.explanation:
Correct answer D) 1, 3, 4

Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs overdiagnosis of breast carcinoma.

True

Widespread mammography detects early-stage cancers and indolent tumors, leading to overdiagnosis and possibly unnecessary treatments.

2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination (DRE).

False

DRE alone is NOT an effective screening test for colon cancer. Preferred tests are colonoscopy, fecal occult blood test (FOBT), and fecal immunochemical test (FIT).

3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection.

True

Oral cancer screening involves visual examination and palpation of the oral mucosa, especially in high-risk individuals (e.g., smokers, betel nut chewers).

4. Cervical cancer screening is done by a Pap smear.

True

Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) detects cervical dysplasia and early-stage cancer, making it the gold standard screening test. HPV testing is also recommended in some guidelines.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old female presents with a 4 x 3 cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A 2 cm lymph node is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is noted in the opposite breast. Which of the following investigations would you perform in this patient? Bilateral Mammography PET Scan Biopsy of the breast mass USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.explanation:
Triple Assessment of Breast Examination

1. Clinical Examination

Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy.

Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes.

2. Imaging

Methods:

  • Mammography: Preferred for women over 40.
  • Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation.

3. Biopsy

Types:

  • FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions.
  • Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses.
  • Excisional: Removes lump for examination.

Triple assessment yields more accurate results than individual assessment.

options.label: C
options.text: 10 follicular cell clusters with 6-8 cells each

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each

Diagnostic category

Risk of malignancy (%)

Non-diagnostic

5-20

Repeat FNAC with ultrasound guidance

Benign

2-7

Clinical and sonographic follow-up

Atypia of undetermined significance

13-30

Follicular neoplasm

23-34

Molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy

Suspicious for malignancy

67-83

Molecular testing, lobectomy, or near-total thyroidectomy

Malignant

97-100

Lobectomy or near-total thyroidectomy

questions.text: What risks are associated with the initiation of tamoxifen in a patient diagnosed with unilateral breast cancer?

options.label: C
options.text: Breast cancer, on the other side

questions.explanation:
Endometrial Carcinoma

Risk factors

Protective factors

  • Age (>50 yrs)
  • Obesity
  • Estrogen exposure
  • Nulliparity
  • Tamoxifen
  • Family history
    • LYNCH syndrome
    • BRCA1 & BRCA2 mutations
  • Diabetes
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Early menarche
  • Late menopause
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy and childbirth
  • Regular exercise
  • Healthy weight management
  • LNG-IUS

questions.text: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?

A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following nerves is least injured during thyroid surgery?
questions.explanation:
Complications of Thyroidectomy

Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding from muscular arteries or slippage of ligature from superior thyroid vessels.
  • Complication: Tension hematoma causing respiratory distress. Management: Immediate re-operation, open sutures, control bleeding, drain hematoma, and close the wound.

Respiratory Obstruction
  • Primary Cause: Laryngeal edema from extubation injury. (Most Common Complication)
  • Other Causes: RLN palsy and tension hematoma.

Nerve Injury
  • Commonly Injured Nerve: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Other Injuries: RLN Injury causing palsy and Cervical sympathetic trunk causing Horner's syndrome. (Options A & B ruled out)

Parathyroid Insufficiency
  • Ligating the inferior thyroid artery away from the thyroid leads to parathyroid vascular infarction.
  • Causes hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) presenting 2–5 days post-surgery.

Thyroid Insufficiency

Total thyroidectomy leads to hypothyroidism and requires lifelong levothyroxine replacement.

Thyrotoxic Crisis

Inadequate preoperative preparation in hyperthyroid patients leads to the release of thyroid hormones during surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery

options.label: B
options.text: Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery

options.label: C
options.text: DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

options.label: D
options.text: Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.correct_answer: C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
questions.explanation:
Breast Reconstruction Flaps

Flaps

Clinical Correlation

Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle Flap (TRAM)
  • Free flap involves using tissue from the abdomen, including both skin and muscle (Option A ruled out)
  • Most commonly used flap but not the best flap
  • It is based on inferior epigastric vessels
  • Disadvantage: causes weakness in infra umbilical region

Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator flap (DIEP)
  • Flap which uses skin and fat from lower abdomen, but spares abdominal muscles
  • Best flap for breast reconstruction as there is no risk of hernia and muscle weakness

Latissimus Dorsi Flap
  • Flap, which uses Latissimus dorsi muscle, skin and fat
  • It is a type of subcutaneous flap based on thoracodorsal vessels.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg; there is no sign of bleeding. What could be the cause of this?

questions.explanation:
Papillary

(Option B)

Follicular

(Option A ruled out)

Medullary

(Option D ruled out)

Anaplastic

(Option C ruled out)

Follicular cells

Follicular cells

Follicular cells

  • Radiation

  • Iodine deficiency

-

BRAF, RET-PTC

PAX-8,/PPAR-1, PTEN, P-53, RAS

RET, MEN II

P53

Clinical Manifestations
  • Seen in the 3rd to 4th decade.
  • Midline swelling in the anterior part of the neck
  • Occasionally, lateral aberrant thyroid is seen.
  • Seen in the 5th to 6th decade.
  • A sudden increase in the size of the swelling
  • Minimal or no pain
  • Raised calcitonin.
  • History of diarrhoea
  • Family history of pheochromocytoma or hyperparathyroidism

 

Metastasis

Lymphatic

Hematogenous

Both

Both and Direct invasion.

Histopathology
  • Optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
  • Dystrophic calcification (Psammoma bodies)

Follicles (multiple foci are seen)

 

 

 

 

Amyloid deposition

 

 

 

 

 

Highly pleomorphic cells, spindle cells, giant cells, often areas of necrosis and mitotic figures.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a serum calcium level of 12.8 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5–10.25 mg/dL) along with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 1.5 x 1.5 cm mass in the right lower lobe of the thyroid gland. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Only observation, no need for surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. MIBI followed by focussed parathyroidectomy to be done

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN2B syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia
 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma

(most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)
  • All the four glands can be included.
  • Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

(Option A ruled out)

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type.

Pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present
  • Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan
  • Metastasis can be traced with PET scan
  • Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia
  • Rx- Prophylactic thyroidectomy

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumours
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus (Option C ruled out)
  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas (Option B ruled out)
  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumour
  • Adrenal tumour

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with occasional palpitations, high blood pressure, and headache. He is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. What is the preferred initial investigation?
questions.explanation:
Pheochromocytoma

Definition
  • A catecholamine-secreting tumour that arises from the chromaffin cells of the abdominal sympathetic chain/ adrenal medulla
  • Co-exist with neurofibromatosis, VHL syndrome, MEN syndrome

Clinical features
  • Classical triad: Headache (most common), profuse sweating, palpitation and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent)
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia and Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor (due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction)
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight Loss

The rule of 10
  • 10% are bilateral
  • 10% are extra-adrenal
  • 10% are malignant
  • 25-33% are inherited
  • Symptomatic patients do not follow the Rule of 10’s

Diagnosis
  • Measurement of the plasma fractionated metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test; hence, the initial investigation is preferred.
  • Increase 24 hour urinary VMA(Vanillyl mandelic acid) and metanephrines (Option D)
  • MRI is the investigation of choice. (Option B ruled out)
  • Biopsy and CT contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid hypertensive crises

Treatment
  • Adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Size<5cm- Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha-blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

Purulent

questions.text: A patient with invasive ductal carcinoma in situ presents with ulceration on skin and inflammatory signs. Nipple retraction was also present. What is the stage?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Stage 3b:

When T is

When N is

When M is

  • T4a- Extension to chest wall Ribs + intercostal muscles + Serratus anterior
  • T4b- The skin changes are involved (All the changes should be confined to the same breast)
    • Ulceration
    • Edema including Peau-D' orange
    • Satellite nodules
  • T4c- T4a + T4b
  • T4d- Inflammatory breast cancer
  • N0- No regional lymph node involvement
  • N1- Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary lymph node level I and II (mobile)
  • N2- Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary lymph node level I and II (fixed/matted)

 
  • M0- No clinical or radiological distant metastasis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. On examination, the mass was larger than 5 cm and ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were present. What is the staging, considering the mass is malignant?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Tumor size (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (DCIS, LCIS, or Paget's disease)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm

T1mi

Tumor ≤ 1 mm

T1a

Tumor > 1 mm but ≤ 5 mm

T1b

Tumor > 5 mm but ≤ 10 mm

T1c

Tumor > 10 mm but ≤ 20 mm

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 5 cm

T3

Tumor > 5 cm

T4

Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

T4a

Extension to the chest wall

T4b

Ulceration or skin nodules

T4c

Both T4a and T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to movable ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or clinically apparent internal mammary nodes

N2a

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted

N2b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes without axillary lymph node involvement

N3

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or infraclavicular nodes, or to supraclavicular nodes

N3a

Metastasis to infraclavicular nodes

N3b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes

N3c

Metastasis to supraclavicular nodes

Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

questions.text: A woman presents with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.explanation:
Disease factors that influence prognosis

Histologic Subtypes
  • Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): Prognosis varies by grade and molecular markers.
  • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC): Intermediate prognosis.
  • Tubular and Mucinous Carcinomas: Best prognosis.
  • Basal-like Breast Cancer: Aggressive, triple-negative, no targeted treatments.
  • Other Subtypes: Medullary, cribriform, papillary, adenoid cystic, and metaplastic carcinomas vary in prognosis.

Tumor Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumour size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumours and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis.

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR):
  • ER-positive = better prognosis, responsive to endocrine therapy.
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies.

Patient factors that influence prognosis

Age

Younger, particularly premenopausal women, may have higher local recurrence rates post-surgery, but radiation therapy can reduce this risk.

BRCA Mutation

(Option A)

Generally more aggressive and associated with poorer prognosis.

Family History

A strong family history may indicate inherited susceptibility and potentially a worse prognosis.

Prior Breast Cancer History

Previous breast cancer can negatively influence the prognosis of a new diagnosis.

Lifestyle Factors

Obesity and inactivity are linked to increased recurrence risk and may affect overall prognosis.

Treatment Adherence

Non-compliance can worsen prognosis.

Patient factors that influence prognosis

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a breast lump and is seeking medical evaluation. On examination, a palpable mass is detected in the breast. Which of the following conditions is not associated with the development of breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Risk factors

Relative risk
  • Female gender.
  • Increasing age.
  • Germline mutations of high penetrance.
  • Strong family history (>1 first-degree relative, young age, multiple cancers).
  • Personal history of breast cancer.
  • High breast density.

>4.0
  • Germline mutations of moderate penetrance.
  • High-dose radiation to the chest at a young age.
  • Family history (1 first-degree relative).

2.1-4.0
  • Early menarche (age <12 years)
  • Late menopause (age >55 years) (Option B)
  • Late first pregnancy (age >35 years).
  • Nulliparity.
  • Absence of breastfeeding.
  • Exogenous hormone therapy (Option C)
  • Postmenopausal obesity.
  • Physical inactivity.
  • High alcohol consumption (Option A)

1.1-2.0

Relative risk is the likelihood of developing invasive carcinoma compared to women without any risk factors.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presents with HER-2-positive breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab treatment. The oncologist is considering the next line of treatment. Which of the following options would be the most appropriate choice?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Treatment

Systemic Therapy

Targeted Therapy: Specific for HER2-positive cancers

Trastuzumab, Pertuzumab, Lapatinib

Chemotherapy: Addresses systemic disease

Taxanes, Anthracyclines, Capecitabine

Hormonal Therapy: For hormone receptor-positive cases (not standalone for HER2-positive)

Tamoxifen, Aromatase Inhibitors (if combined)

Local Therapy

Palliative Surgery: Relieves significant symptoms from primary tumour growth

Mastectomy

Radiotherapy: Controls localised symptoms, especially bone metastases

_

Bone-targeted Therapy

Manages bone metastases and reduces skeletal-related events

Bisphosphonates, Denosumab

Management: IV Hydrocortisone

It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery).
  • ↳ Addisonian crisis
  • ↳ Addison's disease
  • ↳ Management: IV Hydrocortisone
  • ↳ Management: IV Hydrocortisone

Clinical features

  • Glucocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (dilutional), hypercalcemia
  • Mineralocorticoid insufficiency
    • Hypotension, shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • ACTH excess: Pigmentation
  • Adrenal androgen insufficiency: Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females

Investigations
  • Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency)
  • Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency.
  • Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency)
  • Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women
  • Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.

Management
  • Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used.
  • Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone

Addisonian crisis
  • An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery).
  • Management: IV Hydrocortisone

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to conclusively localize a parathyroid adenoma?
Which of the following drugs are not used for thyrotoxic crisis management?
questions.explanation:
Thyroid Storm

About
  • A thyroid storm, or thyrotoxic crisis, is an acute, life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism.
  • It presents with multisystem involvement and has a mortality rate of 8 to 25% despite advancements in treatment.

Etiology
  • Most commonly associated with Graves' disease but can also occur in toxic multinodular goitre and toxic thyroid adenoma.
  • Precipitating Factors:
    • Abrupt discontinuation of antithyroid medications.
    • Thyroid surgery.
    • Non-thyroid surgery.
    • Acute illnesses (e.g., infections, diabetic ketoacidosis, myocardial infarction, stroke) act as stressors that can trigger excess thyroid hormone release.
    • Parturition (childbirth).
    • Recent use of iodinated contrast medium.
    • Trauma or Burns or traumatic brain injury.
    • Medication side effects (e.g., amiodarone, anaesthetics, salicylates).
    • Raised beta-hcg conditions such as complete mole, twin pregnancies

Clinical Features
  • Fever: High temperature (104°F to 106°F) with diaphoresis.
  • Cardiovascular Involvement: Tachycardia (>140 bpm), heart failure, arrhythmias, hypotension, and risk of cardiac arrest.
  • CNS Manifestations: Agitation, delirium, anxiety, psychosis, or coma.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, intestinal obstruction, and acute hepatic failure.
  • Physical Exam Findings: Tachycardia, goitre, hand tremors, moist and warm skin, hyperreflexia, systolic hypertension, and jaundice.

Management
  • Initial Supportive Measures: IV fluids, oxygen, cooling blankets, and acetaminophen (Option A).
  • Beta-blocker Therapy: Start with propranolol (Option D) immediately (40-80 mg every 4-6 hours) to control adrenergic tone.
  • Thionamide Therapy: Administer propylthiouracil (500-1000 mg loading, then 250 mg every 4 hours) or methimazole (20 mg every 4-6 hours). This reduces thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Iodine Solution (Option C): Give SSKI (5 drops every 6 hours) after thionamide to reduce the release of thyroid hormone
  • Glucocorticoids: Hydrocortisone (100 mg IV every 8 hours) or dexamethasone (2 mg every 6 hours).
  • Therapy to block peripheral conversion of T4 to T3: Iodinated radiocontrast agent, glucocorticoid, PTU, propranolol
  • Cholestyramine (Bile acid sequestrant): 4 grams orally 4 times daily for severe cases to reduce enterohepatic recycling of thyroid hormone.
  • Monitoring: Admit to ICU with close cardiac monitoring and ventilatory support if needed.
  • Alternative Medications: Esmolol as a short-acting beta-blocker; diltiazem if beta-blockers are contraindicated.
  • Surgery: Thyroidectomy for patients with contraindications to thionamides after pre-treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Recommend radioiodine therapy or surgery for hyperthyroidism once stabilized.

questions.text: Identify the most common pancreatic islet tumor associated with MEN-1 syndrome.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Gastrinoma

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia

 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma (most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)
  • All the 4 glands can be included.
  • Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

 

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

 

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type.

Pheochromocytoma.

 

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present
  • Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan
  • Metastasis can be traced with PET scan
  • Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia
  • Rx- Prophylactic thyroidectomy

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumors
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumor
  • Adrenal tumor

questions.text: Which of the following are typically done in breast conservation surgery? Wide local excision Axillary node dissection Frozen section during surgery Post-operative radiotherapy (optional)
questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications
  • First-trimester Pregnancy
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse Suspicious microcalcifications on mammogram
  • Extensive DCIS
  • Inflammatory Breast Cancer
  • Tumors for which Clear Margins are Unobtainable with Lumpectomy
  • Homozygous for ATM Mutation

Relative Contraindications
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast
  • Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins
  • Large Tumor Size Relative to Breast Size or Tumors Greater Than 5 cm
  • Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation)
  • Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2)

questions.text: Extra mammary Paget’s disease is commonly seen in the:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Vulva:

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Hormone receptor staining:

Score 1 2 3
Size ≤15 mm 16–40 >40
Margin ≥10 mm 1–9 <1
Class Grade 1/2 without necrosis Grade 1/2 with necrosis Grade 3
Age >60 40–60 <40
